name: MercadoLibre, Inc.
thesis: Elite business, demanding price. This DCF treats lending growth as reinvestment (not free cash). Base intrinsic value is $1,469 (~-26% vs $1,996.87). Bull case $2,433 requires sustained ~30% growth + expanding owner cash generation. Buying here implicitly underwrites near-bull execution.

reverseDCF.interpretation: At today's EV, the market requires terminal EBIT margin ~18% (vs ~14% base) OR a materially stronger growth path (~28% 5-year revenue CAGR) at low-teens owner cash generation. That's a demanding bar.

risks.title: Credit losses spike
risks.detail: If loss rates rise as the portfolio scales, owner cash margins compress quickly â€” the reverse DCF breaks fast.

risks.title: Funding cost pressure
risks.detail: Higher funding costs (rates/competition/regulation) squeeze NIMAL and reduce fintech profitability.

risks.title: Take-rate compression
risks.detail: Competitive pressure or regulation reduces commerce/fintech take rates; growth alone won't save the valuation.

risks.title: Shipping/subsidy creep
risks.detail: Lower free shipping thresholds and logistics expansion can structurally depress gross margin.

risks.title: FX and macro volatility
risks.detail: LATAM FX swings distort USD-reported profitability and raise the required discount rate.

risks.title: Regulatory tightening
risks.detail: Payments/banking-like rules increase capital and compliance costs, reducing ROIC.

risks.title: Reinvestment intensity stays high
risks.detail: If growth requires persistent cash absorption (loans receivable + restricted funds), headline FCF overstates owner cash.

risks.title: Multiple compression
risks.detail: If the market reprices risk (higher ERP/WACC), a great operating print can still see the stock fall.

catalysts: Q4 2025 earnings: margin trajectory + credit quality indicators.
Evidence that growth continues with stable or improving loss rates.
Signs logistics unit economics are structurally improving (not just timing).
Disclosure around capital allocation and long-term credit funding structure.
managementQuestions: What loss-rate / cohort metrics convince you credit growth is scaling safely?
How do funding costs evolve as credit penetration rises (especially Argentina)?
What is the long-run 'owner cash' margin after credit reinvestment?
How durable is take-rate if shipping subsidies increase?
What regulatory changes could force higher capital buffers or constrain growth?
